---
layout: default
title: "Connect to a non-GKE cluster"
--- 

Adding an existing cluster to Pipelines allows you to automate deployments to the cluster, and manage the cluster in Pipelines.

This page covers adding existing non-GKE clusters that are not using Kubernetes role-based access (RBAC). For more information on connecting to an RBAC-enabled cluster, see [Connect to an RBAC-enabled Kubernetes cluster](./pfc_permissions_kube_rbac.html).  

>**Important**: When adding an existing cluster to Pipelines, the cluster management IP address must be reachable by Pipelines on port 443.

Pipelines does not use basic authentication. Instead, it uses certificates for authentication. Regardless of the cloud provider you're using, you need the following information:

<ul>
  <li>a cluster certificate</li>
  <li>a client certificate</li>
  <li>a client key</li>
  <li>a master endpoint IP</li>
</ul>

### Obtaining your cluster certificates, client key, and master endpoint

First, make sure you've <a href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl/" target="_blank">installed <code>kubectl</code></a>, as well as the relevant command-line tool for your cloud provider.

1. Connect to your cluster from the command-line.
2. Use a `cat` command to view your cluster configuration file:

   ```cat ./kube/config```

   A single cluster configuration may look like this:

   ```
   apiVersion: "v1"
   clusters:
   - name: "kubernetes"
     cluster:
       certificate-authority-data: "" 
     server: "https://104.198.1.40"
   contexts:
   - name: "admin@kubernetes"
   context:
     cluster: "kubernetes"
     user: "admin"
   current-context: "admin@kubernetes"
   kind: "Config"
   preferences: {}
   users:
   - name: "admin"
      user:
      client-certificate-data: ""
   client-key-data: "" 
   ```

The fields you need are as follows:

<table>
   <tr><th>~/.kube/config field</th><th>Pipelines field</th></tr>
   <tr><td>certificate-authority-data</td><td>cluster certificate</td></tr>
   <tr><td>client-certificate-data</td><td>client certificate</td></tr>
   <tr><td>client-key-data</td><td>client key</td></tr>
   <tr><td>server</td><td>master endpoint IP</td></tr>
</table>

If you need to create a certificate for Pipelines to use on your cluster, see <a href="http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/kubectl/kubectl_config_set-credentials/" target="_blank">kubectl config set-credentials</a>.

### Connecting to an EKS cluster

If you have not already configured your AWS credentials in the [integrations](./integrate.html) page, Pipelines prompts you to add them before you connect to your cluster.

You need to provide the following information:

* **The cluster name:** This name appears in Pipelines.
* **The cluster region:** The AWS region that the cluster exists in.
* **The Master Node Instance ID:** The AWS EC2 Instance ID for the cluster master node.
* **The Master Endpoint IP:** The master IPv4 endpoint address for the cluster. Include the HTTP or HTTPS prefix. For example, `https://192.0.2.0`.
* **The client certificate:** The cluster client certificate.
* **The client key:** The cluster client key.
* **The cluster certificate:** The cluster certificate.

### Connecting to an AKS, bare metal, or other cluster

To connect to your cluster you need to provide the following information:

* **The cluster name:** This name appears in Pipelines.
* **The cluster region:** The region that the cluster exists in.
* **The Master Endpoint IP:** The master IPv4 endpoint address for the cluster. Include the HTTP or HTTPS prefix. For example, `https://192.0.2.0`.
* **The client certificate:** The cluster client certificate.
* **The client key:** The cluster client key.
* **The cluster certificate:** The cluster certificate.

Now that you've added your cluster, you need to make sure that Pipelines has permission to view and make changes to it. For more information, see [Set cluster permissions](./cluster-set-permissions.html). 

**Related topics:** 

For more information about Kubernetes clusters, see the <a href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/home/?path=users&persona=app-developer&level=foundational" target="_blank">official Kubernetes documentation</a>.
